newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU launches debate on mobile communications.
newsitem.headline: EU launches debate on mobile communications.

text.p: The European Commission launched a debate on Thursday on ways Europe can profit from the new generation of mobile communications technology.

The European Union executive adopted a paper asking for input on how to promote Universal Mobile Telecommunications System (UMTS), a technology that will give consumers global access to multimedia services over portable terminals.

"The mobile communications sector has come to crossroads where answers to key strategic questions, both in the industrial domain as well as in the regulatory domain, need to be found urgently," the Commission said in a statement.
Noting that UMTS will be introduced at the start of the next century, it said in a report that it wanted to open discussion on what policy decisions are needed.

The report highlighted the worldwide success of the GSM digital mobile phone standard that was developed by European companies, saying it had contributed to the well-being of the EU's telecoms industry and ITS economy as a whole.
It said use of mobile communications was growing rapidly in western Europe, where there were now 37 million users

The Commission asked a series of questions, including whether the EU should define a strategy for introducing UMTS or wait before introducing regulations. It also asked whether there was a consensus on whether UMTS would be a single technology or a number of "interoperable solutions".

The Commission said it also wanted to know what roles the private and public sectors should play, how UMTS would affect Europe's industrial competitiveness and how to ensure the "wireless information society" serves broader societal interests.
It said interested parties should submit comments by July 15, after which it would propose appropriate initiatives. -- Brussels Newsroom 32 2 287 6800
